subject: Re: [junit] How to use @DataPoints? in theories
msgSnippet: Berin, My expectations are the same as yours in this case.  This looks like a bug.  Can you file it at http://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues and add the
messageBody:
Berin,

My expectations are the same as yours in this case. This looks like a
bug. Can you file it at http://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues and
add the "bug" tag, so I don't forget? Thanks,

David Saff

On Tue, Feb 2, 2010 at 9:15 AM, Loritsch, Berin C.
<berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
> Just to see how things map, I attempted to do something like this:
>
> @RunWith(Theories.class)
> public class TrackableTestCase {
>        @DataPoints
>        public static Class[] collectTargets() {
>                Class[] targets = new Class[] {
>                        User.class, Incident.class
>                };
>
>                return targets;
>        }
>
>        @Theory
>        public void examineClass(Class klass) {
>                System.out.println(klass.getName());
>        }
> }
>
>
> The problem of course is that the Theories runner couldn't map the
> datapoints to the Theory:
> java.lang.AssertionError: Never found parameters that satisfied method
> assumptions.  Violated assumptions: []
>
> When I did the same thing with Strings, I had no problems.  I did find
> out that the return type had to be an array and not a list.  The
> Theories runner just couldn't map the classes to the theory that took
> the class.  Additionally, when I had both the class data points and the
> string data points, the Theories runner attempted to map the whole array
> of strings to the examineClass theory above.  Unsurprisingly there was a
> class cast exception there.
>
> So what are the limitations of this feature?  Can I use my own defined
> objects?  Does it only get confused when you are trying to feed it Class
> objects?  It is unexpected that it is not behaving properly here.
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
>
>
